DE23B8132AA74C79A4D664398C2ACE7E.description: Provide feedback on own and/or peer business plans.

FBCE2564138043D68657012BA6A71AD0.description: Outline and present a plan for a small business in the early learning and health care industry in one’s community

E91B693309EB4AE4A8C5871351A0B46F.description: Investigate the advantages and disadvantages of owning a sole proprietorship, partnership and/or franchise business.

0537ADAD82404AABA374DB3197363839.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of operating a small business, including a home-based business.

91A81685EE5D49DC8D817332FFE79B73.description: Research the contributions that small businesses make to the local and Saskatchewan economy.

088633808F88447FA3DA1C9DE52DF90B.description: Investigate small business, including home-based, opportunities in the early learning and health care industries in Saskatchewan.

A0C98D5FC53E47B99BB9E37D6D2B7727.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

26EC491645034C87A7C61162D4236FF2.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

087B1145D2B24A29B145E71E5D704436.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

0D8E24E7A5874B79BE979DA8B10919D5.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

997403F639CE4ECEA838AE0F088F8B5E.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

1C5042D39BED4E8F90D7B6AAF662BBEA.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

95F659737E0B4B6CB10529F6DC24BA6F.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

DB90FD8E9C6F45FD857D41E533D51B6E.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

FE69CFBE79174D929811654D1DBE4E40.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

51F5508172E840F8888530E37EE8049A.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

4D5283B37BF542C7949B57EB9226EAF4.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

CB521A241D8E4BB08C00068640851DA7.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

FA0CBEBFDD6A42129059382E4CB6767C.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

5B8B9E83041A4A0A8893CFA6E5D68316.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

AAC2BA54D0C44F64AAA4C48B10AE5DAD.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

D250E73A092A4C3BB4C22AE4A736C68A.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

09E8244C836B4A3E953E745420C734D2.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement

62EBDCD2E07945A691610531E73E598C.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

1FEB4EC115E544DB96B79D294C94E045.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

B6470215CE8E4533811711833F271023.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous

E52F759349554F83BA6148A8FCAA4C7A.description: Evaluate the efficacy of the invitation for learning.

F3576CF387EA4D7BB74CDFA3FB47FFFD.description: Create an invitation for learning for a targeted age grouping (e.g., toddlers, preschoolers).

AFBDB0C533794C9F8CD72F3B74698D69.description: Explore how play schemas and their corresponding loose parts can be incorporated into invitations.

E480D31136E9490A983E588DA3AC8A26.description: Investigate ways invitations could be used to support the cultures of children in the program

0C30A0C4AB7F4D62A614F959380A6DBD.description: Explore materials that could be used in outdoor invitations (e.g., hub caps, hay bales, steering wheels, pieces of wood)

A48A80F4040B44D4BDB6A42A9C06827B.description: Examine invitations that promote literacy and language development.

40C4EBD4E6CF423F8BC3656684C0CD21.description: Explore considerations for designing invitations, including: children explore with their senses (e.g., consider the textures, smells, sounds); children engage with transforming materials (e.g., consider materials that change when manipulated or combined); collections of materials (e.g., consider the amount of materials for the number of children); recycled materials (e.g., consider materials with previous other uses); props and materials (e.g., consider additional materials to add excitement and interest to the invitation); tools for drawing and writing (e.g., consider tools for drawing and writing, ways to record ideas); and • literacy and numeracy development (e.g., consider books, written materials, picture word cards, STEM activities).

C82FD375EBA3486081C09DC0FA1E5DFE.description: Discuss preferred ways to present invitations (e.g., determined focus, visually appealing presentation, materials that define the space, intentional positioning of the objects).

8A59E75F061B454D80AF1B04D8EDD332.description: Observe children engaging with an invitation to determine ways to extend learning and play.

CBE6C2CFBF4B4107900CBECDAE31AF76.description: Describe the purposes of invitations (e.g., they respond to an emerging interest of a child, offer experiences with content knowledge, introduce children to new concepts, events or skills, allow children to perform risk assessments).

C95DB3A9842F4F2CAE532657987905AB.description: Compare thematic planning to child-guided planning.

95ACB62484854995B9FEF3A0C825CB5A.description: Compare an experiential centre and an invitation for learning.

0D25489DC8944095B3874906EAB8877C.description: Define invitations for learning (i.e., a collection of interesting and carefully combined materials that may be used in a number of ways).

C4A956192010441BBDD671E17FE5A374.description: Research local and provincial organizations that offer specialized supports (e.g., Inclusion Saskatchewan, Autism Support Services, Saskatchewan Alternate Format Materials Library, Early Childhood Intervention Program, Kids First, Saskatchewan Prevention Institute).

368A730155E54A0C9DB6FB64DB097573.description: Evaluate an indoor and an outdoor environment for children with diverse abilities.

B025CD5E1F074627B64CE8E200FEB257.description: Demonstrate ways to welcome all children in an early learning and child care environment.

B17ADF984C5A4DC1AE2D3C99DA5F1B58.description: Research specialized professions related to early childhood development (e.g., occupational therapist, speech therapist, child psychologist, behaviour therapist, physiotherapist).

8BBEB3454C6047A7AB29593CD30C5C48.description: Demonstrate the use of circle practices when planning an intervention.

5C210EC0451C4A17AE712AE87BC85CAB.description: Investigate how to conduct strengths-based interventions (e.g., acknowledging skills, knowledge, talents, character traits, relationships and abilities rather than deficits).

C2A8CDFD1B4D4AEE98428F59C05A5383.description: Discuss how to collaborate with other professionals and families to develop a holistic understanding of the child.

F0C7FB81DE2F43BCBD51CCFD6F3AC7D2.description: Investigate the role of the early learning and child care caregiver in documenting and reporting for early intervention (e.g., observe, screen and monitor child development)

F64F9E33B7A641C2B9D7114B75867D78.description: Discuss adaptations (e.g., in learning centres or invitations for learning, daily activities and routines) for children needing universal supports.

77772419D88C445BA587F42A267F257D.description: Investigate adaptations (e.g., in learning centres or invitations for learning, daily activities and routines) for children needing targeted and intensive supports.

66336EF72EDB40AE93D9B42C349EFB8E.description: Describe exceptionalities that may require intensive supports, including: blind or visual impairment; • deaf or hard of hearing; intellectual disability; bipolar, depressive, anxiety or related disorders; autism spectrum disorder; physical health impairment; and, neurodevelopmental disorder associated with prenatal substance exposure

B89406CA69F24E57918EB6F9958E953F.description: Describe strategies for responsive teaching such as making evidence-based decisions, valuing relationships and meeting students’ needs.

C911A1B48A8743858EAF281EA642CA88.description: Explore case studies that demonstrate responsive teaching.

3B1DF7495126452D926AC697FCCB2C1C.description: Investigate needs-based practices such as nurturing student independence, screening for early intervention, engaging families and involving collaborative interprofessional teams.

9F5C618A6880427C96710622AEF3F2FC.description: Compare a medical model (e.g., focus on diagnosis) to a needs-based model (e.g., focus on strengths, abilities and needs of the child).

7E5098CE8D22401B8C266CDD52D1ADEA.description: Define a needs-based approach within the context of early learning programs.

1795D4E6CDDC4E4FA9A1F751D7EEBEE1.description: Investigate characteristics of an inclusive early learning program.

A1F683953578489B9007B9CF62AEF8C6.description: Demonstrate appropriate ways (e.g., terminology) to discuss children amongst colleagues or with parents and caregivers.

4B707BE413D146BB84DA917C43C128AA.description: Evaluate documentation tools (e.g., pictures, videos, products) used to record the four dimensions of learning.

A176EEC225524AFDA8E9611DD666A52F.description: Interview a professional who performs specialized assessments in early learning and child care environments.

D1C41BFD2A8C4E519886315F6937D913.description: Explore specialized assessments completed by professional specialists (e.g., speech language pathologist, occupational therapist, educational psychologist)

F39269A23E0847139F3FE67508EC57DA.description: Differentiate between screening and assessment tools.

19CDB19C6F44488488364E417753B4F2.description: Investigate developmentally appropriate and culturally responsive assessment practices, such as developing a relationship with the child, administrating assessment tools in the child’s first language and allowing children to represent their ideas in a variety of ways.

8612ED226F5B4E5897D0B0E3E4FC144B.description: Investigate the steps of the assessment cycle used by early learning and child care caregivers, including: collecting assessment evidence; analyzing and Interpret evidence; establishing goals and creating a plan; and, implementing plan and evaluating effectiveness

C8B15F1839764E0EBF74CCABA84F9081.description: Differentiate between observation, documentation and assessment.

FC54F271215E4A338506DEB9523F577D.description: Explore assessment and documentation processes in early learning and child care environments.

9EB712F26DAF455B8F01BE13279A6B85.description: Document children’s language and literacy skills related to the intellectual developmental domain of a child using an observation template.

E3BF62C41C7D48D0897267CE1AD04B20.description: Compile a list of language and literacy materials (e.g., songs, rhymes, books) that are connected to cultures, home languages and familial understandings in the community.

4F02C7376A714E90995320A7E9F028DA.description: Research the benefits of bilingualism or multilingualism in early childhood.

E93E8921061A45E680800A6BCF2317A2.description: Discuss ways to support the use and development of home language.

FCE2095039B9490B862D129A07A4F6FF.description: Investigate how young children acquire additional languages (e.g., extended time period to absorb the additional language and build confidence, exploration and play with peers and adults, singing familiar and repetitive songs).

DFD87D2A34E84C9E82F0F249A9549B85.description: Analyze representations of ideas created by children (e.g., drawing, painting, collage, construction, dramatic play).

F455148612F44CB6B643B8204A2C1D74.description: Demonstrate interactive reading with individuals or small groups (e.g., reading with expression, articulating clearly, inviting comments, asking for predictions, sharing feelings and experiences).

165368BDBF804F6FABB6967F06CF9010.description: Research songs, poems and books with texts that rhyme, use alliterations and explore different sounds.

8D7F78A693664290B54A2DDC70780DCA.description: Investigate age-appropriate strategies to introduce new vocabulary in an early childhood setting.

58CEF7D590394AA9966DC76659E5C4C9.description: Demonstrate asking complex questions (e.g., “How does that work”, “Why do leaves change colors?”) rather than simple questions (e.g., “What’s that?” or “Where are we going?”).

B3A1EA2237FF40D4A9C6F7818E0D1F50.description: Investigate strategies used by speech and language specialists to help children engage in conversation.

CF267EAADC2D4444B22C8E4377BBA2D6.description: Identify opportunities for children to listen with engagement (e.g., musical performances, puppet shows, stories, visits from Elders and grandparents).

3EC0FC54D2DF4CD88167DE172778A37E.description: Investigate the stages of literacy development

64A46C8B916243EEB7A32C5F868B2E5B.description: Explore the essential learnings related to language and literacy development, including: listening with interest and engagement during brief experiences with spoken language; engaging in conversation; exploring words; engaging in sound and word play; gaining meaning from a variety of visual formats and text materials; representing ideas and using expressive forms; and, exploring how print works.

E2D217404E4648F094380900B627DC96.description: Discuss how language can be developed through interactions in play.

F59FFC9358114FB28DCA59EDA24EE422.description: Explore language and literacy development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

C999BE87C7C545069A2EEA6639AFEE64.description: Explore language and literacy development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

2BB2ABC54F5445D79513E0EF9D6B7600.description: Investigate how families and communities support and encourage each other in spiritual growth.

E039D438496C4405986AA58994BDB903.description: Create a collection of images that highlight relationships between fellow students, the school, the community and the natural world and discuss how this collection could be used in an early childhood setting.

CC821296C6584FC7B7D44B0D04FDBBBE.description: Share personal reflections on natural and man-made beauty (e.g., a natural space or an architectural monument in the local community).

DDB9B14E881F4313A31E6B1BE7B9836B.description: Brainstorm vocabulary to describe textures, sounds, smells, colours or tastes.

CEBAAE7C5A0A44A38C3B98F87BB3D37E.description: Encourage multi-sensory awareness by collecting culturally relevant materials such as beads, feathers, cones, pebbles, mirrors to capture light or plants with different scents.

8903B808BA0840D7906877F5B862F6CC.description: Discuss ways to safely expose infants, toddlers and preschoolers to the natural world.

C90B83439AB14BE7869519B494680747.description: Examine what captures the attention, engages the senses and triggers possible emotions after walking or spending time outside.

5C74E4B561DC4056AEB52B55D7DD3293.description: Describe a memory of sensory perceptions related to the beauty and wonder of the world experienced as a young child.

6F921A5C9E3A4DF6AFBF840A20260A09.description: Explore the spiritual dimension of development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

B2BB70E33A134554902FECB00B24F8CB.description: Document the intellectual developmental skills of a child in an early childhood setting using an observation template.

A82E1C7B115547CFA5F5C17610C45F59.description: Create age-appropriate activities to explore positioning (e.g. games, art projects, building materials).

18109C3BC9E44B22A7C9660B87824FEA.description: Identify age-appropriate activities to explore the concept of time (e.g., posting a calendar, talking about seasons, planning long-term multi-step projects).

07EC0A2D1DEA45518724E616863A328A.description: Discuss the presence of numeracy in everyday life in an early learning setting (e.g., counting songs, estimating amounts, measuring lengths).

F554C258B1CD46989C7B303D6E0694A5.description: Collect a selection of age-appropriate tools and devices (e.g., measuring tapes, measuring cups, rulers, sticks) children can use for measurement.

4565BFAF2312487E808822592ADD697A.description: Select open-ended age-appropriate materials, including culturally relevant materials, (e.g., loose parts such as bottle caps, sea shells, pine cones, marker caps, rocks, fabrics, containers) to recognize attributes and characteristics.

97716D2ED12D4183862983584FAEA78E.description: Produce a creative representation, construction or prop to play with to encourage toddler and preschoolers to be imaginative with their creations using a variety of materials.

F4D33A6ACF0F43D2AAB3E7D405669A06.description: Explore the essential learnings related to the intellectual domain of development, including: creating and imagining; recognizing attributes and characteristics; exploring numeracy; exploring language and literacy; exploring time; and exploring position and direction.

4B8FE955A2AF496BBB3063F658BED1C4.description: Explore the intellectual dimension of development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

25CF3F4B144E436E8C2A961D7FA491D9.description: Document the social and emotional growth of a child in an early childhood setting using and observation template.

8A5608E20A2340E6AAD83E57B3A73970.description: Model strategies, for different age groupings, to consider the perspective of others and show empathy.

2325C1094A3A456DB4F85BAEDFC9684F.description: Role-play a scene in which an early learning and child care caregiver models strategies to identify and regulate emotions.

68EF1EC61E2A4932A8356D05CB2E1CFE.description: List ways to provide support to children who could have difficulty separating from family to minimize distress.

9EEF251A6F94400497674DF3D86DAFD5.description: Explore the essential learnings related to the social emotional domain of development, including: developing self-awareness; developing self-worth; developing sense of belonging; separating from family without distress; identifying and regulating emotions; interacting with others; acknowledging the perspective of others; showing empathy; and, • resolving conflicts.

CF88E7539D7C4C31A0C07B273F75FC70.description: Illustrate personal early childhood experiences that enhanced sense of belonging in early learning and childcare environments.

25BB4868718C46748D2318265B335CBF.description: Explore self-awareness including name, favorite personal traits, interests, favorite food, extra-curricular activities, community and cultural connections.

05BD7CAEA22E4EA98572503500015789.description: Explore the socialemotional dimension of development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

17CF72582FCD46F6AFBCEC7CA3175688.description: Document the physical developmental skills of a child in an early childhood setting using an observation template.

BDE12E9D13DE439B81BA231E0DD4BB9F.description: Brainstorm strategies to develop healthy habits independently (e.g., wearing a bicycle helmet) when engaging in free play.

5049D53EE5A7410D979806D814141204.description: Lead an activity or game for different age groupings designed to develop an awareness of space by adjusting their movements around furniture, objects, hazards, adults and children in a common space.

8A4028F49D564B56B470EC1BA7C29965.description: Lead an activity or game for different age groupings designed to develop manipulative skills such as throwing, tossing, kicking, catching or striking.

8710486643984730A745C1318A1A1027.description: Design a balance trail for different age groupings to develop stability and balance, in which children must remain upright and maintain balance while moving on various surfaces, slopes and heights.

DCA0CE2DA275468E922D4EF022D77619.description: Prepare materials for different age groupings that provide children opportunities to develop fine motor skills such as strengthening hand muscles, manipulating small items and representing their learning.

BF183CAA1D3E4C3BAD2BAADCB4D4D6CB.description: Create a safe obstacle course for different age groupings in which children use loco-motor skills such as walking, running, crawling, skipping, hopping, leaping or rolling.

7B5C569C6E4B404AB2654DDF65ABB84A.description: Discuss indoor structures, spaces and equipment (e.g., climbing structures, space to dance, balls, scarves) that promote large muscle development for different age groupings

69E4AA70AC544DE2952D49200B441323.description: Differentiate between loco-motor, fine motor, balance and manipulative skills.

5481BD568CE9495F9624771088960C8C.description: Explore the essential learnings related to the physical domain of development, including: developing loco-motor skills; developing fine motor skills; developing stability and balance; developing manipulative skills; and, developing space and body awareness

07588EF618184810820AC6979EAD89EE.description: Identify the benefits of physical activity for young children (e.g., develop strength, flexibility and endurance, maintain healthy weight, lower stress and anxiety).

F5A945EEE412428194D89206F35ED8ED.description: Explore the physical dimension of development for infants, toddlers and preschoolers.

CE0427607685439F9FB176C942DD1F9E.description: Investigate protocols to invite grandparents or Elders to tell stories in an early learning setting.

512282CED5CE4BA9A7C110CB12F47D80.description: Research local events of social, ceremonial and community activities available to families with young children.

FF4462C2DCEB47498D3098DB18A86ABB.description: Describe strategies that can be used in early learning and child care environments to challenge gender stereotypes.

F9FBBB5C35174F2CA54483C34D96321F.description: Identify ways to support and promote identity when working with young children, such as: selecting multilingual books and software; selecting books from two or three different cultures that address the same topic (e.g., trees); selecting music of various genres that reflect the contemporary cultural community; using manipulatives and loose parts (e.g., instruments, toys, rocks, shells) familiar to the children; • learning key words (e.g., hello, goodbye, please, thank you, I love you) from children’s home language; and, • creating object labels in children’s home language

032A4CA53BF34736B617C1BFF2107941.description: Research ways in which early learning and child care environments can support learning an additional language (e.g., through music, literacy, vocabulary building activities).

9C7285537EBD4850A6ED973323B3BE4A.description: Demonstrate ways to include families’ cultural identities in early learning and child care environments (e.g., books, posters, family pictures, orally transmitted stories).

BD493B68D78F4221A687E0E0897F5469.description: Identify the four stages of human life that build identity including childhood, youth, adulthood and old age, using the symbol of the circle.

34231BCDB6E54607B9B3111C67A54CD3.description: Recognize how connection to others, place and language influences identity development.

EEAB96BCE69C4149A703F10B112E721A.description: Discuss current roles (e.g., child, sibling, cousin, niece, grandchild, employee, student) and how they contribute to building identity.

94C186C16E82486D8777CDD3EB5AE481.description: Discuss what it means to belong to a family and a community (e.g., name, parents, grandparents and community affiliations and connections).

BD8DE09AB44A43BC82112BFCBC3255E1.description: Identify ways to support children’s culture, identity and sense of belonging.

98F07E097CB543F28953C86F5878BCA9.description: Research facilities (e.g., libraries, churches, hockey rinks, community centres) or events (e.g., festivals, theatre, dance, music, sport) that build relationships in the community.

489CF30723584C11BF735654E1AB1530.description: Compare the mandates of a variety of community resources for families with young children.

DB9B1F226D134CF3A34769460A637866.description: Identify ways to recognize, respect and incorporate family strengths (e.g., things they know they are doing well, highlighting what is strong rather that what is wrong) when interacting with families.

D66FD7724CEB4BB08AEA219A3992E39C.description: Discuss how parents, caregivers and families are the experts on their child

0BABE02442DA48F7BE978255EA1E9005.description: Describe strategies that can improve relationships and communications with parents (e.g., communication apps, daily verbal reports).

7069CD294E80441DB99E1E9D84250636.description: Discuss ways to include families in planning activities, supports and resources when appropriate.

07E43A22EBA6412EA02182855FA0275D.description: Identify barriers to positive relations between families and early learning and child care caregivers

4C031B2FD7504966A56414B7CA489E73.description: Describe the benefits of developing strong collaborative partnerships between early learning and child care environments and their families.

0CBBA40C66C74258B7AE0AFD4B33F4AF.description: Describe how early learning and child care caregivers can develop positive relationships with families and the community.

6CA301F67DC9484391980F25CCECA98F.description: Identify local organizations that support mental health for young children and their families (e.g., Saskatchewan Prevention Institute).

8BBCBA39570B412BAB7C309826C9F4F8.description: Investigate clinical mental health disorders in young children (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder, regulation disorders of sensory processing, adjustment disorder).

9D729554E6294E358E8EBF1988100571.description: Determine early indicators (e.g., withdrawal behaviour, compulsive activities, loss of earlier developmental achievements) of mental health disorders in young children.

126901ACB89840239C52035E0AC7A6B1.description: Explain the impact of stress on brain development, including pre-natal and post-partum experiences.

DF293CD33A09457BBCBC79118F35C121.description: Distinguish the three levels of stress (i.e., positive, tolerable, toxic) and their impact on child development.

F631FDFD714649619C0F44CAC33B18E2.description: Recognize what can cause stress and anxiety for young children (e.g., moving, separation, residual trauma).

7E06BE71D3A048C59F5F82C78C023C44.description: Describe how to promote secure attachment relationships in an early childhood setting.

129F35A3FCD5414AA0B8656BC62472E6.description: Recognize the nature of the attachment relationship between children and their parents or caregivers.

39B58C51A2F543A1B4D1DD5F9EA5F4BF.description: Research how children’s mental health and development outcomes are impacted by the following factors: child factors (e.g., pre- and postnatal experiences and circumstances, temperament);socio-demographic and societal factors (e.g., community, environment, level of income); and, • parental or caregiver factors (e.g., consistency, parenting attitudes and styles). socio-demographic and societal factors (e.g., community, environment, level of income); and, parental or caregiver factors (e.g., consistency, parenting attitudes and styles).

F13D382179184FA5B69B922C21B41EC9.description: Investigate key developmental theories related to infant and early mental health, such as attachment, resilience and emotional regulation.

113538ABB4104745B571E2FF05288CBD.description: Explore theories and disorders related to early childhood mental health.

82E518060D984FCF9989D87B885915E7.description: Investigate the roles of society in ensuring the safety of children (e.g. Amber Alerts).

0EAA68135077457A9D6DE7114E71C2D9.description: Examine how early learning and child care environments can respect UNICEF’s Convention on the Rights of the Child.

1FF7C6F0E982445EAEEAE95D4C9F9B88.description: Investigate the procedures related to administering medication (e.g., Epi pens, Tylenol, insulin, antibiotics, inhalers) in an early learning and child care environment.

932CBA72778D45D3882ABD330DB4E860.description: Discuss privacy laws that protect children’s records.

E9EF822B71884F4598012342A3A2EFD1.description: Describe the early learning and child care caregiver’s legal responsibility in reporting suspected abuse

207B2EFB56114D678EB48AF851CC77D3.description: Identify possible indicators of child abuse.
